newsitem.title: USA: Yiddish booster Leo Rosten dies.
newsitem.headline: Yiddish booster Leo Rosten dies.

text.p: Author Leo Rosten, who helped make words like klutz, kibitz and chutzpah part of everyday American English with his bestselling book "The Joys of Yiddish," died on Wednesday at his New York home aged 88, friends said on Thursday.
Rosten was best known for that bestseller and for a series of novels on Jewish immigrant life that began with "The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N" in 1939.

Kaplan was an immigrant who butchered English in a night school class where he insisted on signing his name with asterisks as he talked of such great American writers as "Jeck Laundon, Valt Viterman and Mocktvain" and made such observations as, "If your eye should fall on a bargain, pick it up."

Rosten was born in Poland and emigrated to Chicago with his family when he was three years old. Educated at the University of Chicago, he found himself teaching immigrants in a night school class and was inspired by the experience to create the Kaplan books after one of his students.
His "The Joys of Yiddish" is considered the classic text explaining the language of East Europe's Jews to Americans.
